Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) for shelf, coastal, and estuarine oceanographic studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI's requests MRI funding to acquire an instrumented autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) for physical, biological, and chemical oceanographic studies in estuaries and coastal waters. The proposed AUV is specifically equipped for operation in shallow coastal and estuarine environments, and includes: a guidance system that responds to real-time measurements, so that the AUV can be programmed to autonomously follow scalar gradients; a 1200-kHz current profiler, to make higher-resolution velocity profiles; a forward-looking sonar for improved terrain following at low altitudes for bottom boundary layer investigation and work in shallow water; modular payload packages, which increase the versatility of the AUV for either benthic or water column research; and submersible chemical sensors and imaging equipment. Collectively, these capabilities will facilitate new investigations of hypoxia dynamics, larval transport, estuarine physical processes, harmful algal blooms, fisheries, and sediment dynamics.

Broader Impacts:

The broader impacts of note include fostering collaborations, and interactions with the general public and school groups via web portal, displays and demos. The PI's also identify opportunities for including the AUV in ongoing middle/high school HPL programs. Presently, no similarly capable AUV in terms of endurance, navigation accuracy, and instrumentation, is operated within the Chesapeake Bay area and greater Eastern seaboard. Acquisition of the proposed AUV instrument would enhance the infrastructure for coastal and estuarine research and education at the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Sciences. The benefit of the proposed facility to society is the improved understanding of coastal and estuarine marine environments. The AUV will be extremely useful in surveys of coastal and estuarine marine processes of importance to public health and society such as harmful algal blooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We purchased a Hydroid-Kongsberg REMUS 600 with the support of NSF award 1126426. The REMUS 600 is an autonomous underwater vehicle--a propeller-driven underwater robot designed to observe the marine environment. Upon receiving the award, we conducted several meetings with Hydroid, located in Pocasset, Massachusetts, to develop an instrument payload and vehicle configuration that would capable of advancing coastal oceanographic research. The vehicle includes instruments to measure temperature, salinity, dissolved oxygen, chlorophyll fluorescence, suspended sediment, nitrate, and currents. We added a second battery tray, doubling the endurance of the vehicle to more than 40 hours of operation. The acquisition also included the necessary communications and operations support equipment for managing this vehicle, which weighs more than 600 pounds and is nearly 18' long. We took delivery of the base vehicle configuration in Fall of 2013 and have since logged more than 600 miles of underwater time in locations across the Eastern seaboard. In Summer of 2016, ducted thruster modules were delivered; These allow the vehicle to hover and vertically profile.


This acquisition has enabled the integration of novel sensors into the vehicle, supporting numerous projects sponsored by Federal agencies and partnerships with private industry. This work is leading to new discoveries and understanding of the ocean, and the award has also given numerous students and postdoctoral scholars access to this technology, training that otherwise would not have been possible. For example, more than a dozen students will be trained on an upcoming cruise on the new UNOLS vessel R/V Sally Ride. Both of these aspects, enabling technology development and providing training access, are critical to continued advances in coastal oceanography. The coastal ocean is home to some of the most diverse habitats on the planet and plays a critical role in numerous areas of the nation's economy, including fisheries, transportation, recreation, and energy. Our understanding of this dynamic region and our ability to predict future changes is enabled only by the quality of our observations. The vehicle acquired through this award, and the research and training that it enables, is an important part of that discovery process.
